text:
And I thought I was the only one! Content fatigue is definitely real. With the pandemic, it only accelerated the burnout :sob: 

Echoing with the rest, I guess the only way is to either have multiple projects on (with diff industries) or switch industry completely. But if you prefer to remain in your current industry, having your own non-work related hobbies on the side and taking breaks (lots of it!) help tremendously! Browsing through what your competitors are doing also help boost the creative juice in me sometimes :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

text:
Hey all, has anyone established *Quality* guidelines for content? This is something I’m exploring at Maze and I’d love to hear from other people who’ve thought through the question of _How do we know this is a high-quality piece or not?_

I’m also curious if these guidelines differ from a style guide or if you think of them as one and the same thing?

text:
Guest post tip -

Take some time out to check what interests the person you are reaching out to. Personalization will make you stand out of the crowd and once you have a personal connect with the other person it is easier to get things approved.

text:
It's been an always evolving process, but we've had some things going well in this direction.

First, all pieces we craft for us and our clients must answer 3 questions:
- Who is it for specifically (which specific ICP)?
- What problem is it addressing (for each ICP, we have a list of internal, external, philosophical, and desired transformation map we come up with when developing what we call ICP StoryScripts. So each piece MUST focus on one).
- How does this piece advance what we or our client do (how does it support the overarching messaging, what topic cluster does it fall under, what specific features of our service or client's product solves those problems?)

If that 1st part all looks fine, we move to 2nd part, outlining and drafting, which follows 9 steps:
1. Headline alternatives
2. Storytelling hook/filter 
3. Show possibility (why should anyone read this?); subtle CTA 
4. PoV (your unique point of view, storytelling)
5. Show, don't tell.
6. Light CTA
7. More PoV, storytelling 
8. Testimonials, subtle brag
9. Hard CTA

Lemme know if you'll like to see a real example of our StoryBriefs (what others call content briefs)

text: <@U029CJ26CR0> Do you think we could share some of our guidelines for the editing process as it relates to quality?

elements.text: Do you think we could share some of our guidelines for the editing process as it relates to quality?

text: <@UP6K3LYQ7> I will say that our process uses our editing style guide for some of this. They end up falling into the same bucket, but the style guide is probably more comprehensive than a "style guide" on its own would normally be.

elements.text: I will say that our process uses our editing style guide for some of this. They end up falling into the same bucket, but the style guide is probably more comprehensive than a "style guide" on its own would normally be.

text: <@UP6K3LYQ7> we have a company wide style guide that I pull from, but the content-specific guide has key differences. The piece has to meet copyediting standards but also, to Victor’s point above, clearly engage the main topic, answer the main question, etc. Often this has to do with SEO, and part of the quality assessment is about whether/how well the piece addresses the key query. I use Clearscope reports for this.

text:
Thanks everyone! I think what I’m looking for is exactly this - a guidelines doc that pulls together all these different bits of info.

We already have a style guide that’s used across the org and we also do comprehensive briefs for writers, but what I was looking for is something that would pull together these ideas (and maybe add more) to assess quality. This would be used by any editors (just me for now) and also by writers to understand how their pieces are being reviewed and edited to meet quality standards.

I found that _quality_ is very hard to assess as it can be subjective so a document like this would be super helpful.

<@U024K88ECFN> thanks so much! I’d love to have a look at those editing guidelines.

text: I feel like all- or mostly-text “newsletters” are a big thing right now — think substack — deviating from the more traditional marketing practice of image-heavy emails with external links. Has anyone seen any research on this?

elements.text: I feel like all- or mostly-text “newsletters” are a big thing right now — think substack — deviating from the more traditional marketing practice of image-heavy emails with external links. Has anyone seen any research on this?

text:
Hey everyone, I'm curious how in-depth your briefs are when you assign them to your writers or in-house team?

Do you give the core idea and let the writer sculpt the article around that, or do you do most of the legwork and guesswork so all they're doing is crafting the copy? Interested to see what works for different editors to save time and energy on all fronts!

elements.text:
Hey everyone, I'm curious how in-depth your briefs are when you assign them to your writers or in-house team?

Do you give the core idea and let the writer sculpt the article around that, or do you do most of the legwork and guesswork so all they're doing is crafting the copy? Interested to see what works for different editors to save time and energy on all fronts!

text:
I recently started working with freelancers and I send them the topic, focus keyword and word limit. Then I ask them to send me the outline for the article keeping in mind our internal priority pages. Once I receive the outline we send them recorded loom video ( since everyone is in different time zones)  explaining what to expect in the subheading and other sections.  And thats it. 

For in house team I do the same thing like above but also have a call with them for better understanding.

elements.text:
I recently started working with freelancers and I send them the topic, focus keyword and word limit. Then I ask them to send me the outline for the article keeping in mind our internal priority pages. Once I receive the outline we send them recorded loom video ( since everyone is in different time zones)  explaining what to expect in the subheading and other sections.  And thats it. 

For in house team I do the same thing like above but also have a call with them for better understanding.

text: It honestly depends on the topic. I try to be as thorough as possible and give a good amount of information in each outline, but sometimes I just don’t want to do the work.  For example, I recently hired out an article that was stats based and that outline was pretty sparse compared to an outline I did for an ultimate guide that was 300+ words. Some topics are pretty dry, so I give a brief outline but let writers fill in the rest. I always go more in-depth than a title or keyword, though. I like it when my clients do that for me so I always do that when hiring out work for my day job.

text: <@U01J3L8CJRL> Thanks for the answer. Interesting approach with the Loom video, might clear up misunderstandings ahead of time if it's a new topic or longer article!

elements.text: Thanks for the answer. Interesting approach with the Loom video, might clear up misunderstandings ahead of time if it's a new topic or longer article!

text: <@U01J85VRKF1> That makes sense, I think finding that balance between giving just enough info so writers understand the topic at hand vs basically writing the article for them is the key here. I agree with giving more than just a headline or keyword though, I think that'll come back to bite me when writers inevitably ask "what's the purpose here?"
